submodules.Set up Git: At the heart of GitHub is an open-source version control system (VCS) called Git. Git is responsible for everything GitHub-related that happens locally on your computer.
submodules.Connecting to GitHub with SSH: You can connect to GitHub using the Secure Shell Protocol (SSH), which provides a secure channel over an unsecured network.
submodules.Creating and managing repositories: You can create a repository on GitHub to store and collaborate on your project's files, then manage the repository's name and location.
submodules.Basic writing and formatting syntax: Create sophisticated formatting for your prose and code on GitHub with simple syntax.

description: About pull requests Pull requests let you propose, review, and merge code changes. Authentication documentation Keep your account and data secure with features like two-factor authentication, SSH, and commit signature verification. Getting code...

submodules.About pull requests: Pull requests let you propose, review, and merge code changes.
submodules.Authentication documentation: Keep your account and data secure with features like two-factor authentication, SSH, and commit signature verification.
submodules.Getting code suggestions in your IDE wit: Use GitHub Copilot to get code suggestions in your editor.
submodules.Managing remote repositories: Learn to work with your local repositories on your computer and remote repositories hosted on GitHub.
submodules.About GitHub Classroom: Teachers and school administrators can use GitHub Classroom to create virtual classrooms, make and edit assignments, automatically grade assignment submissions, and more.
submodules.About GitHub Education for students: GitHub Education offers students real-world experience with free access to various developer tools from GitHub's partners.
submodules.About GitHub Education for teachers: GitHub Education offers teachers a central place to access tools and resources for working more effectively inside and outside of the classroom.
submodules.GitHub Desktop documentation: With GitHub Desktop, you can interact with GitHub using a GUI instead of the command line or a web browser. You can use GitHub Desktop to complete most Git commands from your desktop, such as pushing to, pulling from, and cloning remote...
submodules.Working with the npm registry: You can configure npm to publish packages to GitHub Packages and to use packages stored on GitHub Packages as dependencies in an npm project.
submodules.Learn GitHub Packages: You can find out more about using packages in GitHub, including viewing and installing existing packages, publishing new packages to GitHub Packages, and, in special circumstances, deleting packages.
submodules.Working with the Apache Maven registry: You can configure Apache Maven to publish packages to GitHub Packages and to use packages stored on GitHub Packages as dependencies in a Java project.
submodules.About GitHub Code Search: You can search, navigate and understand code across GitHub with code search.
submodules.Understanding the search syntax: When searching GitHub, you can construct queries that match specific numbers and words.
submodules.Searching users: You can search for users on GitHub and narrow the results using these user search qualifiers in any combination.
submodules.Finding files on GitHub: You can search for a file in a repository using the file finder. To search for a file in multiple repositories on GitHub, use the path code search qualifier.
submodules.About protected branches: You can protect important branches by setting branch protection rules, which define whether collaborators can delete or force push to the branch and set requirements for any pushes to the branch, such as passing status checks or a linear commit...
submodules.About releases: You can create a release to package software, along with release notes and links to binary files, for other people to use.
submodules.About the repository README file: You can add a README file to your repository to tell other people why your project is useful, what they can do with your project, and how they can use it.
submodules.About code owners: You can use a CODEOWNERS file to define individuals or teams that are responsible for code in a repository.
submodules.Creating a pull request template for you: When you add a pull request template to your repository, project contributors will automatically see the template's contents in the pull request body.
submodules.Reporting abuse or spam: You can report behavior and content that violates community guidelines and terms.
submodules.Adding a license to a repository: You can include an open source license in your repository to make it easier for other people to contribute.
submodules.Configuring issue templates for your rep: You can customize the templates that are available for contributors to use when they open new issues in your repository.
submodules.About custom domains and GitHub Pages: GitHub Pages supports using custom domains, or changing the root of your site's URL from the default, like octocat.github.io, to any domain you own.
submodules.About GitHub Pages and Jekyll: Jekyll is a static site generator with built-in support for GitHub Pages.
submodules.Troubleshooting custom domains and GitHu: You can check for common errors to resolve issues with custom domains or HTTPS for your GitHub Pages site.
submodules.Securing your GitHub Pages site with HTT: HTTPS adds a layer of encryption that prevents others from snooping on or tampering with traffic to your site. You can enforce HTTPS for your GitHub Pages site to transparently redirect all HTTP requests to HTTPS.

description: Apply to GitHub Education as a student Unlock tools and resources for your educational journey. Apply to GitHub Education as a teacher If you're a teacher, you can apply to join GitHub Education and receive access to the resources and benefits of...

submodules.Apply to GitHub Education as a student: Unlock tools and resources for your educational journey.
submodules.Apply to GitHub Education as a teacher: If you're a teacher, you can apply to join GitHub Education and receive access to the resources and benefits of GitHub Education.
submodules.Use GitHub at your educational instituti: Maximize the benefits of using GitHub at your institution for your students, instructors, and IT staff with GitHub Education and our various training programs for students and instructors.
submodules.Learn GitHub Packages: You can find out more about using packages in GitHub, including viewing and installing existing packages, publishing new packages to GitHub Packages, and, in special circumstances, deleting packages.
submodules.Managing GitHub packages using GitHub Ac: You can safely publish and consume packages by building custom workflows that can also build, test, and deploy your code.
submodules.Installing a package: You can install a package from GitHub Packages and use the package as a dependency in your own project.
submodules.Searching issues and pull requests: You can search for issues and pull requests on GitHub and narrow the results using these search qualifiers in any combination.
submodules.Understanding GitHub Code Search syntax: You can build search queries for the results you want with specialized code qualifiers, regular expressions, and boolean operations.
submodules.Searching for repositories: You can search for repositories on GitHub and narrow the results using these repository search qualifiers in any combination.
submodules.Searching commits: You can search for commits on GitHub and narrow the results using these commit search qualifiers in any combination.
submodules.Cloning a repository: When you create a repository on GitHub, it exists as a remote repository. You can clone your repository to create a local copy on your computer and sync between the two locations.
submodules.Restoring a deleted repository: You can restore some deleted repositories to recover their contents.
submodules.Adding a file to a repository: You can upload and commit an existing file to a repository on GitHub or by using the command line.
submodules.Licensing a repository: Public repositories on GitHub are often used to share open source software. For your repository to truly be open source, you'll need to license it so that others are free to use, change, and distribute the software.
submodules.Creating GitHub CLI extensions: Learn how to share new GitHub CLI commands with other users by creating custom extensions for GitHub CLI.
submodules.Using GitHub CLI extensions: Learn how to use custom extensions written by other GitHub CLI users.
submodules.Using GitHub CLI in workflows: You can script with GitHub CLI in GitHub Actions workflows.
submodules.Using GitHub Codespaces with GitHub CLI: You can work with GitHub Codespaces directly from your command line by using gh, the GitHub command line interface.
submodules.Setting guidelines for repository contri: You can create guidelines to communicate how people should contribute to your project.
submodules.Adding a code of conduct to your project: Adopt a code of conduct to define community standards, signal a welcoming and inclusive project, and outline procedures for handling abuse.
submodules.Managing disruptive comments: You can hide, edit, or delete comments on issues, pull requests, and commits.
submodules.Configuring a publishing source for your: You can configure your GitHub Pages site to publish when changes are pushed to a specific branch, or you can write a GitHub Actions workflow to publish your site.
submodules.Creating a GitHub Pages site: You can create a GitHub Pages site in a new or existing repository.
submodules.Managing a custom domain for your GitHub: You can set up or update certain DNS records and your repository settings to point the default domain for your GitHub Pages site to a custom domain.
submodules.Enabling or disabling GitHub Codespaces: You can control which users can use GitHub Codespaces in your organization's private repositories.
submodules.Understanding the codespace lifecycle: Learn how to develop in a GitHub Codespaces environment, and maintain your data throughout the entire codespace lifecycle.
submodules.Introduction to dev containers: When you work in a codespace, the environment you are working in is created using a development container, or dev container, hosted on a virtual machine.
submodules.Managing access to other repositories wi: You can manage the repositories that GitHub Codespaces can access.

description: Creating an account on GitHub Create a personal account to get started with GitHub. Git and GitHub learning resources There are a lot of helpful Git and GitHub resources available.

submodules.Creating an account on GitHub: Create a personal account to get started with GitHub.
submodules.Git and GitHub learning resources: There are a lot of helpful Git and GitHub resources available.
submodules.Working with the Container registry: You can store and manage Docker and OCI images in the Container registry.
submodules.Working with the npm registry: You can configure npm to publish packages to GitHub Packages and to use packages stored on GitHub Packages as dependencies in an npm project.
submodules.Working with the RubyGems registry: You can configure RubyGems to publish a package to GitHub Packages and to use packages stored on GitHub Packages as dependencies in a Ruby project with Bundler.
submodules.Searching in forks: By default, forks are not shown in search results. You can choose to include them in repository searches, and in code searches if they meet certain criteria.
submodules.Searching topics: You can search for topics associated with repositories on GitHub.
submodules.Searching for packages: You can search for packages on GitHub and narrow the results using search qualifiers.
submodules.Deleting a repository: You can delete any repository or fork if you're either an organization owner or have admin permissions for the repository or fork. Deleting a forked repository does not delete the upstream repository.
submodules.Managing a branch protection rule: You can create a branch protection rule to enforce certain workflows for one or more branches, such as requiring an approving review or passing status checks for all pull requests merged into the protected branch.
submodules.Setting repository visibility: You can choose who can view your repository.
submodules.Editing wiki content: You can add images and links to content in your wiki, and use some supported MediaWiki formats.
submodules.Blocking a user from your personal accou: You can block a user to deny them access to your activity and repositories, and to prevent them from sending you notifications.
submodules.Blocking a user from your organization: Organization owners and moderators can block anyone who is not a member of the organization from collaborating on the organization's repositories.
submodules.Creating a custom 404 page for your GitH: You can display a custom 404 error page when people try to access nonexistent pages on your site.
submodules.Adding a theme to your GitHub Pages site: You can personalize your Jekyll site by adding and customizing a theme.
submodules.Troubleshooting Jekyll build errors for: You can use Jekyll build error messages to troubleshoot problems with your GitHub Pages site.
submodules.Deep dive into GitHub Codespaces: Explore more detail about how GitHub Codespaces work.
submodules.Creating a codespace for a repository: You can create a codespace for a branch in a repository to develop online.
submodules.Creating a codespace from a template: If you're starting a new project, you can create a codespace from a blank template or choose a template specially designed for the type of work you want to do.
submodules.Opening an existing codespace: You can reopen a codespace that you have closed or stopped and return to your work.

description: At the heart of GitHub is an open-source version control system (VCS) called Git. Git is responsible for everything GitHub-related that happens locally on your computer.

To use Git on the command line, you will need to download, install, and configure Git on your computer. You can also install GitHub CLI to use GitHub from the command line. For more information, see About GitHub CLI . If you want to work with Git...

Download and install the latest version of Git . Note Most Chrome OS devices from 2020 onwards now have a built-in Linux environment, which includes Git. To enable it, go to the Launcher, search for Linux, and click Turn on . If you are using an...

When you connect to a GitHub repository from Git, you will need to authenticate with GitHub using either HTTPS or SSH. Note You can authenticate to GitHub using GitHub CLI, for either HTTP or SSH. For more information, see gh auth login .

submodules.Connecting over HTTPS (recommended): If you clone with HTTPS, you can cache your GitHub credentials in Git using a credential helper. For more information, see About remote repositories and Caching your GitHub credentials in Git .
submodules.Connecting over SSH: If you clone with SSH, you must generate SSH keys on each computer you use to push or pull from GitHub. For more information, see About remote repositories and Generating a new SSH key and adding it to the ssh-agent .

module: Keeping secrets secure with secret scanning
description: Let GitHub do the hard work of ensuring that tokens, private keys, and other code secrets are not exposed in your repository.

Secret scanning is available for the following repository types: Public repositories on GitHub.com Organization-owned repositories on GitHub Team with GitHub Secret Protection enabled Introduction to secret scanning About secret scanning About push...
Create sophisticated formatting for your prose and code on GitHub with simple syntax.

To create a heading, add one to six # symbols before your heading text. The number of # you use will determine the hierarchy level and typeface size of the heading. When you use two or more headings, GitHub automatically generates a table of...
You can indicate emphasis with bold, italic, strikethrough, subscript, or superscript text in comment fields and .md files.

You can quote text with a > . Quoted text is indented with a vertical line on the left and displayed using gray type. Note When viewing a conversation, you can automatically quote text in a comment by highlighting the text, then typing R . You can...

You can call out code or a command within a sentence with single backticks. The text within the backticks will not be formatted. You can also press the Command + E (Mac) or Ctrl + E (Windows/Linux) keyboard shortcut to insert the backticks for a...

In issues, pull requests, and discussions, you can call out colors within a sentence by using backticks. A supported color model within backticks will display a visualization of the color. Here are the currently supported color models. Note A...

You can create an inline link by wrapping link text in brackets [ ] , and then wrapping the URL in parentheses ( ) . You can also use the keyboard shortcut Command + K to create a link. When you have text selected, you can paste a URL from your...

You can link directly to any section that has a heading. To view the automatically generated anchor in a rendered file, hover over the section heading to expose the icon and click the icon to display the anchor in your browser. If you need to...

You can define relative links and image paths in your rendered files to help readers navigate to other files in your repository. A relative link is a link that is relative to the current file. For example, if you have a README file in root of your...

You can use standard HTML anchor tags ( ) to create navigation anchor points for any location in the document. To avoid ambiguous references, use a unique naming scheme for anchor tags, such as adding a prefix to...

If you're writing in issues, pull requests, or discussions in a repository, GitHub will render a line break automatically: However, if you are writing in an .md file, the example above would render on one line without a line break. To create a line...

You can display an image by adding ! and wrapping the alt text in [ ] . Alt text is a short text equivalent of the information in the image. Then, wrap the link for the image in parentheses () . ![Screenshot of a comment on a GitHub issue showing an...
You can make an unordered list by preceding one or more lines of text with - , * , or + . To order your list, precede each line with a number.

submodules.Nested Lists: You can create a nested list by indenting one or more list items below another item. To create a nested list using the web editor on GitHub or a text editor that uses a monospaced font, like Visual Studio Code , you can align your list visually....

description: To create a task list, preface list items with a hyphen and space followed by [ ] . To mark a task as complete, use [x] . If a task list item description begins with a parenthesis, you'll need to escape it with \ : - [ ] \(Optional) Open a followup...

You can mention a person or team on GitHub by typing @ plus their username or team name. This will trigger a notification and bring their attention to the conversation. People will also receive a notification if you edit a comment to mention their...

You can bring up a list of suggested issues and pull requests within the repository by typing # . Type the issue or pull request number or title to filter the list, and then press either tab or enter to complete the highlighted result. For more...

If custom autolink references are configured for a repository, then references to external resources, like a JIRA issue or Zendesk ticket, convert into shortened links. To know which autolinks are available in your repository, contact someone with...
You can upload assets like images by dragging and dropping, selecting from a file browser, or pasting. You can upload assets to issues, pull requests, comments, and .md files in your repository.

You can add emoji to your writing by typing :EMOJICODE: , a colon followed by the name of the emoji. @octocat :+1: This PR looks great - it's ready to merge! :shipit: Typing : will bring up a list of suggested emoji. The list will filter as you...
You can create a new paragraph by leaving a blank line between lines of text.

You can add footnotes to your content by using this bracket syntax: The footnote will render like this: Note The position of a footnote in your Markdown does not influence where the footnote will be rendered. You can write a footnote right after...

Alerts , also sometimes known as callouts or admonitions , are a Markdown extension based on the blockquote syntax that you can use to emphasize critical information. On GitHub, they are displayed with distinctive colors and icons to indicate the...
You can tell GitHub to hide content from the rendered Markdown by placing the content in an HTML comment.

You can tell GitHub to ignore (or escape) Markdown formatting by using \ before the Markdown character. Let's rename \*our-new-project\* to \*our-old-project\*. For more information on backslashes, see Daring Fireball's Markdown Syntax . Note The...

When viewing a Markdown file, you can click Code at the top of the file to disable Markdown rendering and view the file's source instead. Disabling Markdown rendering enables you to use source view features, such as line linking, which is not...

module: Getting code suggestions in your IDE with GitHub Copilot
description: Use GitHub Copilot to get code suggestions in your editor.

This guide demonstrates how to get coding suggestions from GitHub Copilot in a JetBrains IDE. To see instructions for other popular coding environments, use the tool switcher at the top of the page. The examples in this guide use Java, however other...

Access to Copilot . To use GitHub Copilot in JetBrains, you need either limited access through Copilot Free or a paid Copilot plan for full access. See What is GitHub Copilot? . Compatible JetBrains IDE . To use GitHub Copilot in JetBrains, you must...

GitHub Copilot offers coding suggestions as you type. For example, in a Java file, create a class by typing class Test . GitHub Copilot will automatically suggest a class body in grayed text. To accept the suggestion, press Tab . You can also...

submodules.Improving code suggestions: If you encounter issues with code suggestions, such as conflicting or missing suggestions, you can try the following: Disable Xcode's native predictive text completion: To avoid receiving two sets of code suggestions, you can disable Xcode's native...

description: For any given input, GitHub Copilot may offer multiple suggestions. You can select which suggestion to use, or reject all suggestions. For example, type the following line in a Java file, and press Enter : GitHub Copilot will show you a suggestion....

module: Showing multiple suggestions in a new tab
description: If you don't want to use any of the initial suggestions GitHub Copilot offers, you can show multiple suggestions in a new tab. For example, type the following line in a Java file: GitHub Copilot will show you a suggestion. To open a new tab with...

If you don't want to accept an entire suggestion from GitHub Copilot, you can accept the next word or the next line of a suggestion. For example, type the following line in a Java file: GitHub Copilot will show a suggestion in grayed text. The exact...

Note Comment suggestions are available in Visual Studio 17.14 Preview 2 and later. GitHub Copilot can suggest comments for your code, by analyzing the code you write and generating comments that describe what the code does. For Copilot Free users,...

submodules.Enabling comment suggestions: To enable comment suggestions, you need to configure the comment style in Visual Studio. In Visual Studio, in the Tools menu, click Options . In the left-side panel, click Text Editor . Click C++ , then Code Style . Under the Code Style heading,...
submodules.Using comment suggestions: To initiate comment suggestions, type the standard comment initiator for the language you are writing in (for example, /// ), before the code you want to comment, and wait for the suggestion to appear. To accept the suggestion, press Tab . To modify...

module: Navigating and accepting next edit suggestions
description: Based on the edits you are making, Copilot will predict the location of the next edit you are likely to make and suggest a completion for it. You can navigate suggested code changes using Tab , making it easier to find the next relevant edit without...
You can change the large language model that's used to generate inline suggestions. For more information, see Changing the AI model for GitHub Copilot inline suggestions .

module: Learning to use GitHub Copilot in Vim/Neovim
description: GitHub Copilot provides suggestions inline as you type in Vim/Neovim. To accept a suggestion, press the tab key. For more information and guidance on using GitHub Copilot in Vim/Neovim run the following command to view the plugin documentation:
You can also use keyboard shortcuts to trigger inline suggestions.
